Description: Body sherd of Corinthian Silhouette Style pottery plate; on top, from inside: band in added red; decoration in silhouette style depicting forepart and trace of one hind paw of panther to right; hailstorm as filling ornament; black band and red band at edge of sherd; underside: plastic ring, painted red at outside; to inside three black bands and dipinto in red; surface burnt dark in places.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd probably belongs to the same vessel as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.127.1b. For a parallel, see Boardman (1998), p. 193, fig. 383 (from Tocra).
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (Catalogue, no. 1037)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 93, no. A124)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219, no. 37)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 72, pl. VI, no. 17)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.262)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
